{{Infobox Software | name = IBrowse | logo = [[Image:Ibrowse-logo.png]] | screenshot = [[Image:IBrowse_Amiga.png|300px]] | caption = | developer = [[Stefan BurstrÃ¶m]] | released = 1.0 {{release date and age|1996|07|28}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sasg.com/mui/news.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/19980625173407/http://www.sasg.com/mui/news.html|archivedate=25 June 1998|title=MUI News|date=29 May 1998|accessdate=4 April 2011}}</ref> | latest_release_version = 2.4 | latest_release_date = {{release date and age|2006|12|22}} | operating_system = [[AmigaOS]] | platform = [[Amiga]] | genre = [[Web browser]] | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]] | website = [http://www.ibrowse-dev.net/ www.ibrowse-dev.net/] }} '''IBrowse''' is an [[Magic User Interface|MUI]]-based [[web browser]] for the [[Amiga]] range of computers, and was a rewritten follow-on to [[AMosaic|Amiga Mosaic]], one of the first web browsers for the Amiga Computer. IBrowse was originally developed for a company called [[Omnipresence]], now defunct. The original author has since continued development of IBrowse.
IBrowse supports some [[HTML]] 4, [[JavaScript]], frames, [[Transport Layer Security|SSL]], and various other standards. It was one of the first browsers to include [[Tabbed document interface|tabbed browsing]] as early as 1999 with IBrowseÂ².
A limited OEM version of IBrowse is included with [[AmigaOS 4]].
IBrowse has not been available for sale to new customers since April 2007 when their distributor quit Amiga market<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.amiga.org/forums/showthread.php?t=46919 | title=IOSPIRIT GmbH quits the Amiga market | date=23 March 2007 | accessdate=12 July 2011}}</ref>, although existing v2.x users can download and install the demo version over their existing installation in order to access all functionality.
== References == {{Reflist}} {{Ref begin}} *Fischer, Michael., Meyer, Michael., and [[Michael Witbrock|Witbrock, Michael]]. "User Extensibility in Amiga Mosaic", Proceedings of the Second International World Wide Web (WWW) Conference '94: [[Mosaic and the Web]], October 1994 {{Ref end}}
